awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Police Department as Organizational Machine: Effects of Body Worn Cameras on the Work Dynamics and Performance of U.S. Police Departments
awd_abstract_narration:
The adoption of body worn cameras in US police departments represents a challenge to established ways of policing. This applies to law enforcement agencies as much as officers. For agencies, body worn cameras represent a novel piece of equipment that must be supported through appropriate technological systems and usage policies. Cameras also produce an abundance of video data that policing organizations must manage as well. Considering these demands, this project will identify the impacts of body worn camera technologies on individual work dynamics and organizational operations in US police departments. Specifically, this project will develop a larger IT governance framework to maximize the value of body worn camera technologies for effective policing operations. This project will expand knowledge on the management of public sector organizations that are increasingly enmeshed with wearable Internet of Things technologies like body worn cameras, and research results will inform the development of educational materials in technology management, law and criminology, and information systems. 

A primary goal of this project is to create an evidence-based organization theory and IT governance framework for public sector organizations that are being increasingly embedded with digital technologies in general and Internet of Things technologies in particular. Specific to the impacts of body worn cameras (BWC) on policing organizations, this project addresses three questions: (1) What individual work dynamics and organizational changes are induced by BWC systems; (2) what technosocial governance mechanisms help maximize the value of BWCs in accomplishing police departments' mission; and (3) what empirical evidence explains the effects of BWCs on the operational and mission performance of police departments. This research activity answers these questions through a three-stage research design. First, the investigators will complete qualitative case studies of police agencies by analyzing data collected from interviews, field observations, and document analyses. Second, drawing upon the results of the case studies and in collaboration with participating agencies, the investigators will develop an IT governance framework to maximize the value of body worn camera technologies in accomplishing police departments' missions. Lastly, drawing from data that will be collected through survey and public sources, the investigators will analyze the effect of body worn cameras on the operational and mission performance of police departments across the US.

por.por_cntn:
Since 2010, in response to public demands for police accountability, many US police departments have adopted Body-Worn Cameras (BWC). BWCs are supposed to reduce police use-of-force and promote police transparency, accountability, and public trust in the police by documenting police-citizen encounters with video footage. Systematic reviews of this extensive field of research suggest that BWCs can minimize officers' use of force in specific circumstances, such as forcing officers to activate cameras during every police-citizen interaction. However, BWC technologies have not been found to affect other types of police and citizen behaviors in a consistent manner, including officers? self-initiated stops and searches, arrests, calls for service, or assaults and resistance against police officers. Researchers have discovered public support for police departments' use of BWC technologies. Also, while BWCs have been shown to lower the frequency of citizen complaints against police officers, it is unclear whether these reductions are due to improved police-citizen interactions or a change in reporting processes. Therefore, our study was motivated by these mixed findings regarding the effects of BWC technology in US police departments.

To address the mixed finding in earlier BWC research, our research combined two research methods: (1) a qualitative case study that involves in-depth interviews with 42 police employees in US police departments, and (2) a quantitative study that involves a nationwide survey of 338 US police departments that use BWCs. Based on the analyses of qualitative interview data, we built a research model that explains how BWCs have affected work routines in police departments, and how the changed routines affect policing performance. The survey research was conducted to validate the efficacy of our research model developed from our qualitative research.

The analyses of the quantitative survey data collected from the national survey supported the efficacy of our research model built from the analyses of the qualitative interview data. In other words, our quantitative survey research confirms the positive impact of BWC technologies on changes in police routines (e.g., in terms of case reporting, citizen interaction, citizen complaint resolution, and officer supervision routines). Also, changes in police routines exhibits the positive impacts on the performance of police departments (e.g., in terms of policing performance and public relationship performance). Importantly, our research presents empirical evidence that technology-induced routine change is central in explaining how technology-induced routine changes exhibit greater explanatory power on police performance than technology alone.

Our empirical findings are significant in that they improve the previous BWC research model. In other words, whereas previous BWC research has measured the direct effect of BWC technology on police performance, our research presented empirical evidence that the effects of BWC technology on police performance are mediated through changes in police department routines.
